Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Compared to Beats Pro by Dr. Dre
Item.Review:
Pros: Sound, comfort, amazing bass, price
Cons: Honestly, nothing. These are perfect.
I am a musician and a producer, so for me, sound quality is everything. In the studio I need headphones with a perfectly balanced sound, and clear reproduction of the sound image. These headphones might not be the best studio option due to the excessive bass. However, I was impressed with their performance in the high and mid range, considering the name-sake "Extra Bass." I was lucky enough to be able to compare these back to back with the Beats Pro, and my conclusion surprised me.
Beats Pro By Dr. Dre When I first put these on there was one thing that struck me. And that was the surprising LACK of comfort for a pair of cans with such a large ear cushion. That isn't to say that the ... y are uncomfortable, but they don't live up to their appearance. Now on to the sound The highs were clear, and well defined, if not a bit piercing at times. That was one of the key differences between the two products: On the beats the highs felt separated, as though they are coming from a different source then the rest of the music. This is not a huge problem, and the difference isn't terrible noticeable, but it does give them a colder sound. The warmth of the bass and mids somewhat made up for it, but they didn't have the same warm feel that the Sony's have. The Bass was strong, and felt well rounded. They did a good job of blocking out external sound. All in all the sound was very good, relatively clear, but not as warm as I would have liked.
Sony MDR XB500 These headphones are without a doubt the most comfortable pair of headphones I have ever worn. They feel amazing. I put them on, and immediately wanted to test the extra bass, so I played several of the most bass-heavy tracks on my iPod. They sound absolutely amazing. The sound is warm and clear, with the emphasis obviously on the bass, but that is not for lack of highs or mids. In fact, I was very impressed with the refinement of the sound in all aspects. The highs were a little dull, but not to a point where they are drowned out, ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: The BEST headphones I've ever used.
Item.Review:
Pros: The SOUND!!!!
Cons: These aren't for jogging.
I bought these for my wife, but I wish they were mine. -The bass performance is fantastic, better than other powered headphones I've tried which I think distort the sound and balance of the music. Plus there are no batteries to replace and no batteries to make the headphones heavier. -The cushions that fit over ears are quite big and comfortable. They block out ambient sound much better than most noise-cancelling phones I've tried. For better or worse, with these on you won't hear much what's going on around you. I have to remove them when anyone talks to me. Again, you get this without batteries. -The headphones are lighter than they appear. They are a big large and bulky looking, but when I took them out of the pa ... ckage, the lightness was surprising. -The cushioning that sits on your head looks thin compared with other over-the-ear headphones. I was afraid that without bigger cushions to sit on my head that they would not be comfortable over time. It is not an issue at all. Perhaps cause they are really light or I have a hard head. You decide. -The cable is flat, thin and about 1/4 inch wide--not round like most headphones. I am not sure what advantage or disadvantage this is but I think it looks cool and might be less susceptible to the common wire issues of most earbuds with the too skinny wiring that breaks over time. There is a cable on each side of the head. There is a small R and L for correct orientation. -The headphones fit my wife well who has a smaller head. They also fit me well, even though I have a larger head. No comment, please. They can accomodate heads much larger than mine (yours?). -They seem sturdy, but I have not owned them long enough to decide. Or my wife hasn't. I keep forgetting they are hers. -The cable length seems OK. Not too long but not too short either. -My recommendation. Get them. I tried them out before I bought them. They sound better than the Bose and others I tried which cost a lot more. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: A friend and I have been searching for great headphones that had a great sound for under $100. Between him and I, we purchased 6 sets of headphones and even though they were good, we still wasn't satisfied. I came across these Sony MDR-XB500 headphones and they might be the ones we have been looking. I have listened to music with these everyday and they perform every time. The sound quality is superb for the price. A lot of reviews I read said the highs can get drowned out by the bass but I don't think so. It's still really clear with a low bass. However, I would like it if the bass had a harder hit but that's still very small thing. Maybe purchasing the XB700 (50mm) or XB1000 (70mm) would produce a harder bass hit. The comfort level on these are amazing. It's like having two pillows aro ... und your ear. I wear glasses and it's still comfortable with them for extended wear. The cord is the flat style so it doesn't tangle up easily or at all. The length of the cord is a little shorter than normal but for what I use it for, it's perfectly ok. I'm usually listening to music/videos on the computer or my mp3 player that's in my pocket. Also, I love the 90 degree bend on the headphone jack. The design and look of the headphones is just awesome. It looks very nice and feels very durable. It's not too heavy, but not too light either to feel flimsy. Sony did a really good job with these and for the price, it's even better. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Dre Beats have nothing on these!
Item.Review:
Pros: Worth every penny.
Cons: Slightly fragile (I think).
I love these headphones. I had tried them in the store while just browsing, not really looking to buy anything, but once I put them on, and played Me & You by Nero on full blast, I knew I had to get them. It didn't hurt that they were on sale either.
The first thing you notice when you put them on is how comfortable they are. They're so squishy! Also, they fit all the way around your ears. Then when you begin listening to them, you notice the insane clarity. They are designed to handle 4-24,000 Hz, so you hear every frequency. The bass (which is what I bought them for) is amazing! I can feel my head vibrate! It's like having computer speakers right on your ears. As a matter of fact, I just put them on the t ... able sometimes to use as speakers. They are sort of noise-canceling as well, which is a plus. In the mornings before school, my friends try to talk to me, but I can't hear a single thing they're saying. The only thing that I don't like is that they feel slightly fragile. I'm very careful with them, and I bought a replacement plan for $15. Anyway, for the price, these are incredibly worth it. I would easily spend over $100 for headphones of this quality. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Durable; Comfortable; Good Value; Great Sound; Good Bass; Lightweight; Stylish; Compact
Spectacular deep bass, immersive sound quality, beautiful design, and great comfort. The Sony Extra Bass headphones achieve all of these attributes easily. These XB headphones present an acoustic epiphany between your ears. The Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass headphones deliver pulsating bass performance with superb vocal clarity for music, movies, and games. In reality, this Sony product represents the finest technological achievement in the stereo headphones product category. The Sony MDR-XB500 audiophile headphones offer ultimate comfort with its highly adjustable plush headband, and pillow quality king-sized ear cushions that cover the most advanced 40mm dynamic headphone drivers on the plan ... et. I am unable to hear other outside distractions in my immediate environment when wearing the Sony stereo headphones. The Sony MDR-XB500 headphones are so comfortable that it is just disappointing to remove them after an exhilarating and lengthy private listening session. The concert venue sonic experience offered by the Sony headphones makes me feel as if a live band is performing right in front of me. No matter what musical preference that you have, the sound reproduction emanating from this beautifully designed pair of headphones is so wonderful, that there is no comparison in audio quality with other headphone brands on the market. The Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass headphones demonstrate extraordinary and prodigious bass output that is instantly addictive. In my judgment, the audio sounds better through this pair of Sony XB headphones, than a component stereo system playing through Hi-Fi tower loudspeakers. The Sony Extra Bass headphones sport an attractive appearance with its large over-the-ear design, sturdy construction, cloth-covered headband, silver ear cup exterior finish, and a 3.9 ft. flat Y-type cord. Of course, the Sony MDR-XB500 headphones feature a sealed acoustic design for improved sound isolation characteristics, direct vibe structure for the highest quality sound output, 3.5mm gold-plated L-shaped stereo mini plug for maximum signal transfer and compatibility with the widest range of portable audio, video, MP3, computer, and home audio equipment possible. The Sony Extra Bass headphones provide the following feature set for the dedicated deep bass fanatic : two channel stereo reproduction, 40mm diameter XB drivers, neodymium high-energy magnets, dome type speaker drivers, L/R ear cup placement markings, extended low frequency response diaphragm design, gaskets, pressure-relieving ear cushions, 1.8" ear cup thickness, 3.7" ear cup diameter, Copper-Clad Aluminum Wire Voice Coil, lightweight tangle-free flat cord, adjustable headband for maximum comfort, over-the-head circum-aural closed design, 1500mW power handling capacity, 4-24,000 Hz frequency response, 40 ohms at 1kHz impedance rating, 104db/mW sensitivity rating, black/silver exterior finish, and this unit's weight is 6.53 ounces without cord. The Sony headphones come packaged with a carrying pouch for storage or safe transport to another destination. I primarily use the Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass headphones with my Sony CFD-G700CP XPLOD boombox to achieve out-of-this-world exact sound performance. The Sony headphones include a 90-day parts and labor limited manufacturer warranty. The Sony headphones are suitable for use at home, at work, on the boardwalk, on the ferry, at the gym, the hotel room, business travel, at the library, the local coffee shop, and the bookstore. It's also an excellent choice for year round use to listen to classical music, classic rock music, hard rock, punk rock, disco, blues, jazz, opera, and country music. Please note that you will need a 1/8" to ¼" stereo headphone plug adapter to connect the Sony MDR-XB500 headphones to a home stereo system. I use a headphone extension cord with the Sony Extra Bass headphones when I listen to a component based stereo system. With its world class bass performance, exceptional midrange, and stunning... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I have been used MDR-XB500 for about a month. It is very light headphones and has good design. It is easy to adjust the size so it would perfectly fit to your head. However, since it is not fordable, I do not recommend this to people who travel a lot with headphones. It has two large ear cups. They are good to cancel noise from the outside, and they produce really good extra bass sound. I use my headphone to listen music (classic, pop, hip-hop, any kind of music) from my ipod, and laptop. The extra bass sound is really awesome; especially, when I listen to hip-hop music. In addition, it is also good to watch action movies. Any sound of gunshot or punch sound makes me excited with this headphone.

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Price/Quality ratio, Bass, Comfort
Cons: Treble, Upper Mids
Pros: Deep well extended bass, rather clear sound, comfort Cons: Rolled off highs and upper mids.
Unfortunately I do not have the packaging or accessories for the XB. I am borrowing these from a friend and the box has been since thrown away.
Design and Build Quality
The first thing you'll notice is how huge the pleather pads are. They look rather silly to be honest, but actually provide a nice seal around the ears and help provide decent isolation. The pads are also very comfortable, though they get warm during extended listening. The headphones themselves are made of plastic, there's nothing special here but they feel solid enough. On either side of the headband where it adjusts So ... ny is written. Below that on the cups the model number and side indicator is given.
Each cup has a flat sturdy feeling cable coming from it that meets at the Y-split. The cables feel flexible and well made. The Y-split is simply a blank plastic almost rectangle that combines the two sides. The cable terminates into a gold plated 3.5mm L shaped plug which feels well made.
The XB500 won't bat any eyes with it's plastic build but it feels well made regardless. The comfort provided by the enormous pleather pads is fantastic and the XB500 sit light on the head while feeling secure. For the $50 these can be had for I haven't found another full-sized headphone that has the comfort the XB500 have. Above average build quality here.
Sound Quality
These have had at least 50 hours of use from my friend so I jumped right in to listening.
The model is called the XB500, which stands for Xtra Bass. The XB500 do not fail on that department. These are certainly basshead headphones and are capable of pumping out some serious bass that's not only well extended, but surprisingly well controlled with good speed for the quantity. The bass is certainly the focus here and it gives the headphones a warm sound. On bass heavy tracks I find my ears vibrating, though the bass isn't as overwhelming as I would e ... expand » « collapse

These are also a lot lighter than they look. Very durable, thich plastic. They look alot better in person too. They also dont need batteries, which is great .Only cons would be that they leak a little buut really not much. Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Product Review for Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass Headphone
Item.Review: The bass in these headphones surpasses anything to be expected for a headphone of it's pricerange. The boomy feel provides that hardcore vibe that EDM/Techno/Rap listeners love. When EQ'd properly, these headphones provide an incredibly solid, powerful bassline, that doesn't muddy up the highs or mids. The highs are powerful, and quite unique, actually, though without an EQ or amp, they can sound quite bright, or harsh at times. The mids unfortunately are not as defined, and unless you EQ them, they will not deliver as expected. These headphones are incredible for you dubstep heads out there, though for you metal fans, it may be better to stick with another line. However, even if you own a high-end pair of headphones , these headphones are a great, fun piece to add to your hi-fi collection ... , and they'll have you appreciating deep, powerful bass. These headphones truly live up to their advertising, and I've thoroughly enjoyed the experience. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Lots of bass but not hifi quality
Item.Review: These headphones are disappointing because despite the wide frequency range claimed on the box, when you listen they lack detail and sound muddled with all but the simplest pieces of music. The closed back design causes the treble to sound compressed; the bass extension is good but can be too much if you turn the volume up high. I had to turn down the bass on my amp which is a first! I did have a positive experience with my old ipod video 5g which until now has never managed to produce any bass whatsoever. With the ipods EQ turned off these headphones actually sound quite good, but then i'm not going jogging wearing these. Construction is reasonable, and they are very lightweight and comfortable but the cable is far too short unless you're using a portable player. On balance, OK i ... f all you want is bass but not recommended if you're into your hifi. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: My listening preferences tend to be very bass-heavy. Theses headphone do not disappoint - they are able to reach all the lows very nicely. Because I do most of my listening while working by the computer, I wear headphones for extended periods of time. The puffy cushions aren't just pretty - they are comfortable. All day long. Some of the highs get muddied, but some tweaking of the EQ, and it's more than acceptable. The headphones deliver as promised - with extra bass. The only real downside I've encountered is the cord: much too short, even when I'm at my desk. I would've preferred a single cord instead of a Y-type, but it hasn't been a nuisance yet. For the price, if you love listening to deep bass (my go-to is trance), you shan't be disappointed. I promise.

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Exactly what I was looking for!!!
Item.Review:
Pros: Excellent quality, deep rich bass, comfort
Cons: Cable a little short
I hate shopping for headphones. When you're shopping for headphones, you can read reviews all you want, but everyone is going to have a different opinion on sound quality, comfort, and design. If the majority of the reviews are good, then you know you will more than likely be happy with that certain headphone, but more than once I've been burned by this method. With this headphone, I've finally found what I'm looking for though.
For the price, these headphone I'll say are the best around, hands down. The audio quality is the best I've ever heard, with the 40mm drive units actually screwed to the structure vs. being glued on like some of the other cheaper headphones. The bass is actually bass, n ... ot just a vibration in the headphone like others. I'll sometimes have to turn down the volume because the bass pressure can cause me to get a little nauseous. The comfort is top notch. The king size ear cushion may look goofy, but the quality of the leather and the comfort of the cushion are the best I've seen yet. I have piercings in my ears, and having these headphones on doesn't irritate my ears like other over-ear headphones have. My ears do sweat a little, but not enough to make it uncomfortable. The flat cord is nice as well, keeps it from getting tangled.
All and all I'm extremely happy with this purchase and would recommend anyone who wants good quality, audio rich headphones at a reasonable price. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: comfort, sound, design, price
Cons: none
Most headphones either lack bass, or clarity. Not these xb500s, first point tho is the ear pads, and the headband. These are the single most comfortable to wear I have ever had, or tried. Even my 450 dollar AKG K-701s are not this comfortable. The earpads are over stuffed, I mean they are puffed up. The leather feels real good, very high quality, the stitching looks like it is hand sewn, very very nice, like a top high-end leather sofa. The headband is made with soft leather and is padded too, not as stuffed, but soft padded. The cord is medium length and is stylishly flat, seems sturdy. The drivers are screwed into the chassis, not cheaply glued in, 8 screws each driver. I was shocked. Those drivers sound supreme too. Deep ... bass, I mean deeeep. Punchy, and booming when needed. I ran subwoofer test and calibration tracks and these things just nearly took it all. Loud and deep, or pounding bass you can feel them. Stunning(dangerous too if not careful, I was getting dizzy and sick), unlike I had feared the bass does not drown out the vocals, mids or highs, and the soundstage is very accurate. These headphones do what the skullcrushers fail to do, deliver impressive bass, and accurate high definition sound. I highly recommend these over the dre beats(I wasn't impresses they sounded hollow) the skullcrushers, or the bose. They beat them all, looking and feeling good expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: The MDR-XB500 Headphones are incredible. They sound amazing. I searched far and wide for cheap headphones with respectable bass and these did not disapoint. Overall if you are searching for headphones under 60$ and your main concern is bass these are the best for you. Compared to the Dre Beats these are better. They cost less and deliver comparable quality. They sound a bit better with an amp as these headphones are conservative in their use of power. They are nice and cozy, but when its hot your ears can get a bit sweaty. They are best for bassy genres such as Rap, Hip Hop, and Dubstep. If you do get these put on 16bit - FRZR9000 and at the 55 second mark and you can feel your head LITERALLY shake. The highs and lows are good but the bass. If you want bass BUY THESE.

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Good price, comfortable, bass response, mids, highs
Cons: Carrying case, lack of features, a little large
It seems to be a trend nowadays for people, especially teens, to buy headphones based on their bass response. Headphone fanatics and audiophiles bash this trend saying that it is killing what music is supposed to sound like. Well, bass lovers, audiophiles, I have some great news, there is some middle ground!
Now, I am not saying that these are going to please the most particular audiophiles, but I will say that these are easily some of the best headphones for under $100. As usual, I will break it down in terms of sound quality (lows, mids, and highs), comfort, and durability.
Sound Quality: Lows: The name says it all, these have the boomiest, yet cl ... ean, bass you can possibly find in a pair of headphones. Even into the lower octaves, the bass remains smooth. This comes with some downfalls because the bass can drown out some of the music at times, but simply setting your listening device to a "Treble Boost" EQ will easily fix this problem.
Mids: Very warm and pleasing to the ears. The bass can drown them out at times, but a simple EQ selection will fix that right up.
Highs: Very accurate and well replicated without being too harsh. You won't be cringing at every cymbal crash and hand clap.
Cofmort: The over-sized memory foam ear cushions make for a pleasing listening experience. These things literally feel like clouds. This is by far the most comfortable set of headphones I have ever worn. They are also surprisingly lightweight. Even after long listening periods, I felt no discomfort or heat problems.
Durability: Although they are made out of plastic, they definitely don't feel fragile by any means. Very well built overall, but since the case provided is only a cloth case, you have to be careful when carrying them around.
Now for some side notes: There is no 1/4 inch adapter, so you're stuck using anything with the stereo mini input. Also, as I listed before, the carrying case is not very reassuring. These do leak noise as well, so I would not recommend them fo ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Whoa. Like, Fat Sound- Sony Strikes Again..
Item.Review:
Pros: THE SUPER THICK and BROAD Soundstage
Cons: I went through 3 pairs of others before finding these..
Well. All-righty then. I'm in love with these things. I use an iPod touch and with the Acoustic preset I'm completely and totally satisfied. They are quite fat, super wide, and expansive to say the least. They are a bit bass heavy with a flat EQ , but then they are extra bass phones, yes?? The sensitivity is great, I'm impressed. I need mid level volume to drive them for average listening ONLY. They get quite loud and maintain their sound quite nicely. Actually they are meant to be driven a bit I assume as the highs and mids come up out of the bass and I'm still only 3/4ths the way up on my volume. Weaker players will have ZERO problems driving these and home systems will ... be just that much thicker. After even a few minutes of listening you'll likely be spoiled as they truly add thick and CLEAN bass and present such a FULL soundstage without the need for empty sounding bass boost settings.
I listen to broad range of stuff which these cover incredibly. Even older stuff and kind of thin stuff sound really well. I go fom Basia, Keiko Matsui to the extreme of Pantera type stuff and these are really one-EQ-setting-does-it-all phones. You'll hear the shortcomings of poorly produced stuff as well as be blow away with the great works..
Being a headphone nut and having finicky ears I can FULLY recommend these for full-time phones- as long as you're okay with the look.. I don't even care with sound like these things generate. For those that think it's overkill- Heck with Em'!! Trust me- They'll have NO CLUE as to what is transpiring between your ears..
The 4ft cord is perfect for portable use and it's a flat and wide ribbon-type that will NOT likely short out. These things are made very well and the cushy ear cups are supposed to be soft and plush- they isoloate the sound well enough, the sound is so thick that they can't help but block out noise.. And the fact that the earcups unscrew from the bad is cool- when the cord gets all warped, which they always do, just take em' ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Best $80 I Have Spent in a While
Item.Review:
Pros: Big, Clean sound from top to bottom. AWESOME Bass.
Cons: I haven't figured out the "not so great" part yet.
There are better headphones out there -- if you want to spend a lot more money. If you're in the sub-$100 range, I don't think you can do much better. I have more expensive headphones that will only gather dust now. These were an impulse buy after I hooked them to my smart phone in the store. The are great on my Creative Zen mp3 player, and totally awesome on my PC. I shook them down with a variety of dubstep, rock, pop, etc. The ultimate test came with Bass Addiction and Bass Mekanik. These 'phones produce big, clean sound from bottom to top -- no mud, boom, or tin. Pure joy for eighty bucks. I'm hearing bass that I never heard before, without blowing my ears and ... brains out. The response range of the drivers allows reproduction to to sub-audible frequencies, but you can still feel it. I might buy a nice $300 set of headphones someday, but that purchase has been postponed indefinitely. The Sony MDR-XB500 is just plain GOOD. That's the final answer from an audiophile sorta guy with eclectic musical tastes, particularly for a 58 year-old bass freak who has listened to LOTS of stuff over the decades. In addition to thunderous, clean bass, I want clean repro to the top. Again -- You can spend LOTS more and get something better, but I'm just plain tickled with this $80 purchase. Getcha the Sony MDR-XD500 headphones. Plug 'em into your PC or your 'Pod, or mp3 player and get happy. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: Spectacular deep bass, immersive sound quality, beautiful design, and great comfort. The Sony Extra Bass headphones achieve all of these attributes easily. These headphones present an acoustic epiphany between your ears. The Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass headphones deliver pulsating bass performance and vocal clarity that represent the finest technological achievement in the headphones product category. This pair of Sony MDR-XB500 audiophile headphones offers ultimate comfort with its highly adjustable headband and plush pillow quality ear cushions that cover the most advanced 40mm headphone drivers on the planet. I am unable to hear other outside distractions in my immediate environment when wearing the Sony headphones. The Sony MDR-XB500 headphones are so comfortable that it is just di ... sappointing to remove them after an exhilarating and lengthy private listening session. The concert quality sonic experience offered by these Sony headphones makes me feel as if a live band is performing right in front of me. No matter what musical preference you have, the sound reproduction emanating from this beautifully designed pair of headphones is so wonderful, that there is no comparison with other headphone brands. The extraordinary and prodigious bass output of these Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass headphones is addictive. In my judgment, the audio sounds better through this pair of headphones than a stereo system playing through Hi-Fi loudspeakers. The Sony Extra Bass headphones sport an attractive appearance with its large design, cloth covered headband, silver ear cup exterior finish, and flat Y-type cord. Of course, the Sony MDR-XB500 headphones feature a 3.5mm gold-plated, L-shaped stereo mini plug for maximum signal transfer and compatibility with the widest range of portable, MP3, and home audio equipment possible. The headphones come packaged with a very high quality carrying case for storage or safe transport to another destination. I primarily use the Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass headphones with my Sony CFD-G700CP boombox to achieve out-of-this-world exact sound performance. With its world class bass performance, exceptional midrange, and stunning vocals, the Sony MDR-XB500 Extra Bass headphones embody the ultimate portable audio accessory. Good Luck. Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Bass headphones, but with some drawbacks
Item.Review:
Pros: Amazing Bass. The Sound Is Very Crisp And Clear. Good Value.
Cons: Treble Gets A Bit Muddy. Very Claustrophobic.
I bought these headphones on a whim. At first I loved them, the bass is super rich and clear. Dubstep has never sounded better :) However, if you listen mainly to rock or any music with notes in more of the mid/high range, these might not be for you. Sometimes vocals get a bit muddy and drowned out by the instruments. A lot of my grunge now has a treble equalizer on it, which has made the sound for these headphones much better. Also, they are very tight and conforming around the ear so they can get claustrophobic! All in all, they are a great value and the bass is fantastic, however, they do have some drawbacks.

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Comfort and bass
Cons: Quality
Originally purchased the Sennheiser HD-205 because I was turned away by the quality of the MDR-XB500 when seeing them in the store. The Sennheiser was, like many other reviews indicate, too tight and subsequently uncomfortable.
The next day I returned to Best Buy to return the Sennheiser for the MDR-XB500 and I am extremely pleased. I actually listen to a lot of rap music, so the extra bass does wonders.
Anything without a lot of intended bass needs an equalizer change to hear some of the other highs and mids since the bass is so apparent.

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Great sound quality
Cons: short cord
These Sony headphones are great quality for the price. I bought this for $55 last year at FYE music store. I think the original price was almost $80. The sound quality is amazing very clear and crisp. The bass is just fantastic. It makes you get lost in your music. No matter what music you are playing it definitely gives a nice rich sound without the ruffled sound if the volume is up too high. The ear cups are very comfortable that fits well over the earlobes. They are also not heavy and does not bog down on one's ears. However,after a while it tends to get a little warm around my ears if I had the headphones on for quite a while. The wire is not very long so you cant be roaming around if hooked up to a laptop or desktop. One does ha ... ve to adjust the EQ if you do not like the default settings. It has lasted me for over a year now so it is without a doubt durable. If you have the volume on to the sound does travel outside of the headphones so people nearby can hear what you are listening to. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Amazing bass in a medium sized package
Item.Review: The XB500 delivers very deep subwoofer-style bass that is uncommon in most headphones. Because they use more traditional 40mm drivers (unlike it's big brother the XB700) it retains a bit more punch in addition to solid deep bass. But because it uses the 40mm driver instead of the 50mm driver in the XB700, the bass does not go as low and there is a bit of negative impact on the midrange during heavy bass. No worse than other 40mm headphones however. The ear cups are the same soft cushions as found on the XB700, except they are smaller. It's just a bit too small to completely surround my ears but a bit too big to comfortable rest on my ears. It rests on just the outer edge of my ears which feels odd. When I use them I fold my ear lobes so they fit inside the cushion and that is the bes ... t way I've found so far. I don't really have big ears. These are excellent for portable use, and sound great without the need for equalization. At 40 ohms they are very easy to drive. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural

My son LOVES them! He said the bass was unbelievable and that the ear phones were comfortable. My husband and I listened and were definitely pleased with the sound. I had purchased the Skullcandy skullcrushers to find a better bass in my highs and mids, but instead i brought them back to get this Sony MDR-X500s, they are very comfortable and sound amazing with almost any genre of music you use.
Sound Quality: If you're computer has a good sound ... card and you play WOW, COD, or Csource, you will like their amazing bass depth, as well as its sound from rap and r&b. These headphones are very good value for money, as they sound as good as Dr. Dre beats in my opinion.
Durability and Comfort: Most of my headphones last 6 to 8 months with heavy usage, these look like they are better quality than some more expensive ones. These headphones are also very comfortable, sometimes i don't even feel them on my head, there is the bass to remind me.
Overall: expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I primarily use these headphones for listening to music while I work. I have traditionally been a Bose fan, but my finances would not support another pair of Triports. On the positive side, headphones are very comfortable, even wearing glasses. I can wear them for hours at a time. The sound is good, the extra bass is a little bit misleading. They have good bass, but it's not overwhelming. Sound is fairly well balanced. Headphones are quite light for their size.Negatives include a bit of muddy mid-range in certain types of music. Here is where the Bose blow these out of the water. However, I can buy 3 pair of these for 1 pair of Bose, so I try to keep it relative.Overall, I'd recommend these for $50-60. If I had to pay the [$] retail I would just spring for the Triports.

The audio quality is a huge step up from earbud headphones and definitely beat the skullcandy extra bass phones which seemed overwhelming and had muffled vocals. I actually think these are even better than sonys noise cancelling headphones which seem to make your head feel its going to explode from the vaccum seal. I personally EQ the bass down and the treble up a hair on my ipod which ... is as easy as picking the treble booster equalizer setting and they sound GREAT. So much detail comes through that you'll never hear with earbuds. For the cons...i'm not much of a complainer in general and I am totally satisfied. I would just watch if you're looking to buy them for recording you'll need another cord to extend the length as the cord on these is only long enough for computer or mp3 player use. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Reproduces the low frequency bass very well. Great Price
Cons: Bulky
I have been DJing for twenty years and have had many headphones. Everything from Sony, Shure, Sennheiser, AKG, Numark, Audio-Technica, Stanton, Denon, American Audio, Nady, and Bose. I always came back to Sony because of the sound quality you get for the price. I have never needed the noise-cancellation because I always have one earphone off anyway. Now I own three headphones: Sony, Beats by Dre, and Bose. If you are considering Beats by Dre, then save your money and buy these. They certainly give Dre (Monster) a run for his money. When it comes to low frequency modulation, these things reproduce it so well that they almost jump off of your ears. If you need noise-cancelling, then these are not for you ... . That's where the Bose comes in. You won't hear ANY outside noise with the Bose headphones. In conclusion, if you are searching Best Buy for headphones, you can stop looking, these are the ones you want. If you want bass, these are the ones you want. If you want to pay a lot of money for the nearly the same sound quality, then buy Beats by Dre. If you need superior noise cancellation buy BOSE!!!

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural

In short, I bought the Dre Beats because of all the reviews that said they have AWESOME Bass. Well little did I know that all of the people that said that were basing their opinion off the store display and did not really own them. So I bought them. That was a mistake. In a few short days I learned that these Sony XB500's had just as much Bass as the Beats By Dre for one quarter of the price. Pros: Big but well-balanced sound, extremely comfortable, affordable.

I was looking for a set of over-the-ear headphones to replace my earbuds because I got tired of jamming them into my ears all the time. I wasn't looking to spend a crazy amount of money so I first tried the Skullcandy Hesh. While they were very comfortable they just didn't have a very full sound. I understand that a pair of headphones in that price range isn't going to sound like a set that costs several hundred dollars, but they were definitely lacking nonetheless. After some research online I decided to give these Sony headphones a try. I am blown away by how great these sound for something at this price point. They advertise these as "extra bass" but I think they actually sound quite balan ... ced. While the bass is most definitely there, it's not so intense that it will rattle your brains. The sound quality really is amazing from top to bottom. And they are ridiculously comfortable as well thanks to the big and plush earpads. As far as durability goes, they don't seem like they will fall apart as long as you don't beat them up. I am sure there is stuff out there that would hold up to more abuse, but these seem like they are made fairly well. If you don't really want to throw down hundreds of dollars for a high-end set of headphones but you want big sound and comfort...you really can't go wrong with these. I highly recommend them. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Accounts for all frequencies, sound quality, and comfort
Cons: not anything
These headphones are phenomenal. Every aspect about them is great. I consider myself an experienced listener, and these are great not just for bass, but other ranges as well. These headphones are able to maintain a quality output of mid-ranges/treble while delivering deep bass. If you are looking for headphones with great bass, snag these; whatever you do, do not get the skull crushers (unless you are a careless bass freak). The skull crushers' bass just drowns out everything ever. And when your subwoofer dies, your left with no bass and horrible sound quality, in re of mid ranges and treble. I primarily listen to rap, although I am pretty balanced, and these headphones suffice for the anything ... in the spectrum of music genres. I read a review earlier that said the bass drowns out everything and I was flabbergasted, considering that what I valued most was the maintaining of the other ranges while having dope bass; it's just like balanced so perfectly and possesses such clarity with a significant dose bass, which blends very nicely. So that guy was just a silly bassophobe. These are so worth the price, but I mean if you are willing to spend the money then you can buy some beats, although you won't be attaining much more quality. Oh and these have some sweet features such as a flat cord, deep ear cups for ill acoustics; they're also just wicked comfy and yeah, buy them. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: guilty pleasure but a bit snug
Item.Review:
Pros: low bass
Cons: maybe too tight
I bought these headphones to wear at work, where my work area isn't at all private and I need to cut down on distractions. I have plenty of smaller headphones and more expensive ones that I don't want to leave at work, so I'm looking for comfort and some sound isolation.
My test listening has hardly been with the kind of music I imagine Sony targeted these for. Sony can't seem to decide between "extra" bass, "accurate" sound and (on the one page owner's sheet, "booming bass"). For us traditionalists, I don't think there's a response curve to be found anywhwere.
As an audiophile who loves accurate sound, including very low bass, I can only describe my reaction to the sound as "guilty pleasure". I put on a group saxophone album ... at random, and the lowest notes of the baritone sax came through loud and clear, without overpowering the rest of the group.
I briefly listened to some FM radio, and even the female announcer's voice (or her surroundings) were bass colored ever so slightly; these phones won't be good for just anything.
Though bass-heavy, these phones don't seem to have a "band pass" effect (those car speakers that only seem to boom at one pitch); take that as good or bad depending on your taste.
The headband is a bit tight for my size 7 5/8 head, so I'm not sure I'll be able to keep them, but I'm going to give them a try-out at work. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: First off, these headphones are very comfortable because the ear cushions are very soft. You won't find many ear cushions this soft and squishy. With that said, they do start to hurt but only after about 3 hours of uninterrupted use. The bass is definitely not lacking at all and sounds great for a bass head like me. I listen to a lot of pop/hip hop as well as some alternative rock. The high range is a bit lacking but that's obviously not the focus of these headphones. For the price, the sound is very good. If you plan on rocking these on campus, just know that they are very big. Flattening the cushions down will help.

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: clear sound, puffy and comfortable cushioning, sturdy build, bass
Cons: large cushioning
The MDR-XB500 creates clear audio with extra bass. This extra bass isn't too overpowering, and all styles of music sound great. I've listened to techno, hip hop, and pop rock (like The Script). The ear cushions are a bit large, but it doesn't bother me. I tried these headphones at my local best buy, and compared it to Beats By Dre Solo HD. They both sounded great, but Sony's product was more than $100 cheaper. I'm not an audiophile, so I couldn't tell the difference between the sound in the two headphones.
If you're a real audiophile, however, get the Solos. From the reviews I've read, the Beats are one of the best noise-isolating headphones out there. Using the MDR-XB500 at ... home, I can [barely] hear outside noise, so the Beats are probably better in that aspect. Personally, I don't think noise-isolation is worth $100 more.
Make your decision by testing headphones at your local best buy. expand » « collapse

Almost all of the sample songs were hip hop songs and the bass was there, just not very powerful. I even tested the Bose Around-Ear headphones for $140 which had a much fuller and powerful bass, but not overpowering for those who don't want thumping bass.
For the average music listener, if you like listening to music with high rich quality and a little more bass, get these. I'd recommend these to alm ... ost everyone. You'll get much more than you're paying for! However, if you're looking for bass or love booming bass like I do (I have subs in my car) I wouldn't get these; I'd go with the Skullcandy Skullcrusher DJ Headphones with Subwoofers for just about the same price. expand » « collapse

Item.Review: i use these for everything, but i watch you tube videos. the sound is rich, not tinny or irritating like some can be. the pads hug the ears to keep outside sounds from distracting you. there is one small complaint but not to take it away from a 5 star rating. that's the wide headband on top. it's padded but it's still just a big hard. maybe if they had narrowed it down a bit; it's so wide. like i said, not much of a complaint. they do fit snug and you don't get the outside sound distractions so you dont have to turn your videos up so loud. things sound great with these. i'll have them for a long long time.

Item.Item: Sony MDR XB500 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Great overall sound, extremely comfortable, and a good price!
Cons: The Cord is a bit short
I like most have had problems with headphones that cost 10-30 dollars because they end up going bad before 6 months and can be very uncomfortable and pricey after awhile. So yesterday I was researching for a new pair. As you can see this has very good reviews so I went to the store to give them a shot. You will notice the quality immediately by just putting them on. Your ears feel as if they are on pillows. Extremely comfortable. The sound is what was truly going to sell me. And it is truly has some of the best sounds for headphones I may have ever heard (Dr.Dre were the best and I had just tried those out prior to these). But what seems logical to you? Paying $250-$300 for Dr.Dr ... e or $80.00 for these which are extremely close in quality and still a great brand name (Sony). If you are picky about your headphones like I am then these are a great choice for you. My friends who have tried out my pair have loved them and wish they had it. As I said earlier this does have a rather short cord but its not a make or break point on buying them. I mean if you require having a cord where you need to use a rubber band to tie your cord then these are not for you. But they rarely present a problem in regards to the cord so I am perfectly fine with it. What others have wrote for their reviews is pretty much on dot. I saw one guy mentioned his ears were sweaty after about 3 hours of use because of these head phones ( have yet to go 3 hours at once) but I am only assuming the sweat is caused by the headphones getting him/her into the song intensely. Oh and the Bass. Lets just say it wont disappoint you ;). But what is best is that its "not" just Bass. The voices are very clear and mend well with the bass. One of my best investments for music. expand » « collapse

I was a little worried about their size and wearing them around because of the giant cushions, but after wearing them outside once, I kept getting complimented on them, so you shouldn't worry about that.
